result.title: Objective
result.description: The Mexican Protected Area system is spatially configured and managed to increase resilience to the adverse impacts of climate change on biological diversity

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: The Mexican Protected Area system is spatially configured and managed to increase resilience to the adverse impacts of climate change on biological diversity

baseline.comment:
1. CONANP has a Climate Change Strategy, but resilience to CC is not reflected in planning and management instruments
2. CONANP budget does not address resilience activities. No multisectorial coordination platform exists regarding efforts and investments on PA at a subnational level.

target.comment:
1. CONANP planning and management instruments mainstream CC resilience
2. Internal budgetary restructuring to allocate 10% of CONANP budget to resilience activities. Multisectorial platform to attain budgetary coordination.

actual.comment:
1.
- CONANP’s legal framework includes CC and resilience (100%).
- Mainstreaming of resilience instruments within the PA system is being done in 9.6% of the CONANP areas.
During Year 1, the inclusion of CC resilience concepts and its attendance have been successfully included in the legal framework of the Mexican PA system:
- CONANP Strategy for 2040
- -PNANP 2013 – 2018
- -ECCAP updated and aligned with public and institutional policy (PNANP) and legal national framework related to CC.
The instrumentation of CC attendance is being carried in 9.6% of the total federal PA in Mexico, covering nearly 30% of national terrestrial and marine biodiversity.
Collaboration agreements with other institutions are being arranged. From Year 2, this represents an opportunity window to promote CC resilience concepts in their planning and management instruments to decrease biodiversity vulnerability towards it.
Special focus on 17 PA by the project is currently undergoing with field representatives that promote the CC resilience instruments in the planning instruments and management activities. It is through the Annual Operative Programs of each PA that specific activities are being executed to detect and attend potential impacts of CC on biodiversity.
2. Collaboration agreements with other institutions represent the first step towards multisectorial coordination. From Year 2, coordination is being promoted to achieve the development of the multisectorial platform.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Financial sustainability to increase resilience of Mexican PA system

baseline.comment:
CONANP budget does not address resilience activities.
No multisectorial coordination platform exists regarding efforts and investments on PA at a subnational level.

target.comment:
Internal budgetary restructuring to allocate 10% of CONANP budget to resilience activities.
Multisectorial platform to attain budgetary coordination.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Mexican PA system readiness framework effectively safeguards BD.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Institutional framework strengthened to increase PA resilience from CC impacts and risks.

baseline.comment:
CONANP framework includes:
-National PA Program (PNANP) 2013-18 and CONANP Strategy for 2040 are under construction
-ECCAP provides general guidelines towards resilience but not aligned with public and institutional policy

target.comment:
-CONANP Strategy for 2040 and other Institutional Plans include CC and resilience
-PNANP 2013 – 2018 includes CC and resilience
-ECCAP updated and aligned with public and institutional policy (PNANP) and legal framework related to CC

actual.comment:
- CONANP Strategy for 2040 include CC and resilience (100% achieved)
- PNANP 2013 – 2018 includes CC and resilience (100% achieved)
-ECCAP updated and aligned with public and institutional policy (PNANP) and legal framework related to CC (100% achieved, document in press)
During Year 1 efforts have been focused in getting the technical elements for the inclusion of the conceptual framework of Climate Change and Resilience of PA of the key institutional frameworks, bottom-up as well as top-down. This has contributed to the alignment to national public policies of the regulatory framework of CONANP, in the PNANP 2014-2018 and ECCAP, fulfilling the guidelines established in the General Law on Climate Change, article 7, section III (regarding the obligations of federal institutions of having a National Program with an element of CC and a Strategy facing Climate Change).
In order to achieve attention to climate change and resilience in PA in the long term, such topics are integrated in CONANP 2040 Strategy as a substantial axis.
During Year 1, the implementation of the Strategy for the Climate Change from Natural Protected Areas has begun according to the four elements it dwells in. The Project has supported this instrumentation through the elaboration of tools to make an early diagnosis of the art state of each PA.
At present Rapid Diagnosis of Vulnerability to Climate Change (DRV) has been performed in 7 out of the 17 PA in the project. DRV is a tool that has been specifically designed for CONANP and it allows for a first impression on the level of vulnerability facing climate change. This tool gives guidance on the prioritizing of actions, but above all it stands as a first step towards the elaboration of Programs of Adaptation to Climate Change (PACC). This document is a complement to the PA Management Program which allows for a more dynamic decision-making process in the PA in a context of climate change, improving management and strengthening operations. It can be estimated that application of DRV in all PA within the project shall be completed towards the beginning of Year 2. Based on the results given by this tool, the conformation of work groups has begun on 7 of the 17 of the Project’s PA of action, with the attendance of field officers, academic representatives and authorities of the municipalities.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Planning, Management and Information System for decision making to mainstream CC into integrated land-use planning that increases biodiversity resilience

baseline.comment:
- No PA has CC resilience mainstreamed in its planning and management instruments
- No National Climate Information Portal for Protected Areas exists
- 0% PAs with access to Portal

target.comment:
- National Climate Information Portal for Protected Areas established with geospatial data, including an Early Alert System and linked to the already existing monitoring efforts (as SNIB, INFyS and SIMEC and other relevant initiatives).
- 100% PAs with access to Portal and staff trained to use it to make effective resilience-based management decisions.

actual.comment:
- The National Climate Information Portal for Protected Areas is in an early stage of development (20% achieved).
- Training in existing monitoring efforts as an action of adaptation to climate change was carried on in 13 PA of the Project.
Incorporation of CONABIO as a responsible partner of the project as derived from the substantive revision of ProDoc, will promote its development in year 2.
This collaboration will give the Project the chance to get information of the MAD-MEX platform (Monitoring, Reporting, Verification Activity Data in Mexico for its acronym in Spanish), that was developed for the REDD+ Program. The close work with CONABIO and CONAFOR as a second partner, will allow us to get information on degradation because it intends to estimate annual changes in the extension of forest ecosystems. Obtaining this kind of data, will allow decision maker of the PA to identify those spots where changes in land use and potential points of landscape degradation are perceived. Also, this will enhance the capacity to make scientific based decisions (Outcome 3).
- Sistema de Alta Resolución de Monitoreo de Diversidad y Degradación (SAR-MOD)
The Project participates in the initiative of the Sistema de Alta Resolución de Monitoreo de Diversidad y Degradación (SAR-MOD) on ecosystems with a participation of 76% of the project PA. Ecosystem monitoring is complementary to the institutional efforts taking place nowadays in relation to monitoring, along with other projects conforming the climate change monitoring system of CONANP.
This tool is intended to analyze Ecosystem Integrity (IE) by means of an approximation by modeling of the complexity of the structure and function of ecosystems. In collaboration with Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, the Mexican Fund for the Conservation of Nature and the Fund for Protected Areas, 23 PA have already attended and in Year 2 they will reach 33 PA.
- Effective resilience-based management decisions
One work of regional impact of climate change in the PA Mariposa Monarca was carried on with the purpose of attaining greater scientific information needed in decision making during the implementation activities and in the mainstreaming of the concept of Climate Change and Resilience.
Another two work on the same topic is being promoted in the Islas del Golfo – California PA and in Constitución de 1857 PA. They will be finished and published during Year 2.
On year 2, consultancy related to the characterization of sites and environmental services will take place in the remaining 14 PA, related to their expected response to climate change.
This kind of work helps to identify actions and responses to possible impacts of Climate Change, in order to strength the PA Management Programs and the Intersectorial Coordination Instruments.
By means of integrating the concepts of Resilience and Climate Change to the Annual Operative Programs (POA) of the Protected Areas in the projects, priority conservation activities have been mainstreamed with an adaptive approach based on ecosystems.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Institutional framework strengthened to increase PA resilience from CC impacts and risks.

baseline.comment: - Communication strategy provides limited promotion of conservation areas as instruments of resilience

target.comment: -Communication Strategy (by Year 2) promotes the importance of conservation areas as instruments to (a) increase resilience of communities and ecosystems and (b) maintain integrity across the landscape/seascape

actual.comment:
- Communication strategy during Year 1 has focused on spreading the concept of Resilience of PA facing CC within the institution.
During the first stage an awareness campaign took place around those publications of institutional planning which show the connection with the national program framework regarding Climate Change. They are distributed electronically via the Climate Change site of CONANP, as well as in print.
1. Publication of ECCAP in an executive summary format with a print run of 5000 copies in Spanish and 5000 in English.
2. Publication of the 2040 Strategy in the form of 5000 copies of the full text, 5000 executive summaries and 5000 posters to be distributed among all personnel of PA.
3. 400 copies of DRV Tool are published for its distribution and use within PA.
Besides the physical and digital distribution of the documentation, the project is spreading the official information through the participation in the meetings of Advisor Councils of the PAs. In order to make aware of the changes in the legal framework of the institution to the personnel of CONANP, the project has made agreements with the Internal Communication department to spread the information through the CONANP’s structure.
Parallel to these actions, a Project Fair was organized as the closing event of the First Series of Conferences on Climate Change (see further details in Outcome 3). It was sought to make known those projects implemented within PA about mitigation and adaptation to Climate Change within the country. The head of CONANP identified the potential of this initiative and as a result gave instructions to the Directorate of Strategies for Climate Change to support the more advanced project as a reference point for other PA since its characteristics are an example of the application of strategies for the adaptation to climate change. A Second Project Fair is planned for Year 2 with a different approach: to encourage PA to present small projects that improve system resilience. On Years 3 to 5, the Project looks forward to developing the permanence of resilient projects that can be applied in PA in the first place.
The objectives of this strategy are also designed to allocate areas of coincidence between national policies regarding climate change and the commitments of UNDP as shown in CPD 2014-2018 in order to effectively communicate the results observed in those communities and ecosystems where the project is applied.
In Year 2, the communication strategy will attempt to widen its coverage to include differentiated audiences according to the nature of the message and to the media used. In the beginning it promotes the identification of the most efficient approach to identify the importance of preservation of PA facing the 3 outcomes of the project. Thus, during this period in the report, a second series of audiovisual materials “Faros de Esperanza” has begun its production, intending to promote PA as a natural solution to CC.
The first series was developed before the beginning of the Project, but it had a positive impact as a diffusion strategy to the specialized and general public. As a result of this, the second series was conceived as a need to be included in the communication strategy.
Besides, along with the development of abilities in field officers, there are plans to produce support materials to strengthen the spread of the concept Resilience with the cooperation of experts from Stockholm Resilience Centre and UNDP. These collaborations are the result of the development of a common concept of Resilience in PA, developed during the international seminar carried on in Morelos, Mexico during Year 1. This event was designed to achieve a common scientific knowledge on the concept with a complete description and measurable indicators, to interchange experiences, and to create synergies with international institutions that could lead to the development of educational materials that could impact the general and the specialized public.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Expansion of PA system to protect important refugia through connectivity and increased resiliency.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Expansion of areas of conservation in priority ecoregions and refugia facilitated by GIS database, measured by the increase in area under conservation to promote connectivity and protect important refugia.

baseline.comment: 0 ha (total ANP 25,384,818 ha)

target.comment: 25,984,818 ha: At least 600,000 ha of new areas included in new or existing conservation areas nationwide: Coastal/marine: 369,139 ha, Terrestrial: 230,861 ha. By Year 2 a strategy will define distribution between the 12 ecoregions (linked to the information system and GIS from Outcome 1)

actual.comment:
- 0 ha of new areas have been included in the National Protected Areas System, never the less 37 thousand ha have been identified by social counterparts for conservation in the surrounding areas of PA. Along with these, more than 1 million ha are in process of being declared as a part of the NPAS in the Sierras La Giganta and Guadalupe in the state of Baja California Sur.
During Year 1 of the Project, there have been identified and prioritized 2 sites for expansion and connectivity of the PA that are part of the Project. The process of validation of those areas as expansion sites strengthening connectivity will be carried out during years 2, 3 and 4 to reach over 37 thousand ha distributed as follows:
1. Voluntary conservation sites in Chihuahua strengthening PA Janos with 16 thousand ha.
2. Support for redefining the estate at Cañón del Sumidero and the potential update to the category of PA Villa Allende, both in the state of Chiapas, with a potential of 21 thousand ha.
Synergy was achieved towards strengthening connectivity while intending conservation activities to be planned and operated regionally, along with PA state system comprising La Pera, Laguna Bélgica and Cerro Meyapak. The participation of these PA as a whole alongside the Project is of the utmost importance since they hold Subsecretariats of Environment, Forest Development and Climate Change within their structure.
The project has strengthened the preliminary supporting study and accompanied overall process, including consultation and institutional meetings in order to declare Sierras as PA, by means of the inclusion of the conceptual framework of Climate Change and Resilience. This will promote connectivity among PA in the region (El Vizcaíno, Bahías de Loreto, Balandra and Sierra La Laguna), increasing conservation surface in at least 1 million ha.
During year-end 1, it is being carried out a study on the current situation and extension of marine reserves in Región de Grandes Islas y Norte del Golfo de California. This will allow for the identification of refugia sites of conservation and of potential connectivity channels. The results shall be ready at the end of the second quarter of Year 2.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Area of functional connectivity between critical habitat blocks surrounding and within PAs maintained or increased to enhance ecosystem resilience through ecoregion-based incentive schemes

baseline.comment:
0 ha
General incentives exist for BD conservation

target.comment: 30,000 ha that enhance connectivity and ecoregion incentives schemes, as a partial result from management actions from Outcome 3. 12 eco-region based incentive schemes/portfolios that enhance resilience

actual.comment:
- 0 ha. The scientific research to identify the potential areas of functional connectivity between critical habitat blocks have begun
Priority conservations sites have been identified by means of analysis of ecoregional system of monarch butterfly, an indicator species. Its migratory path was registered to identify priority habitat blocks. It was found that the species transits through 12 different vegetation types in the country, over one third of the types present in Mexico. A former study identified that over 35,540 km2 correspond to the remaining natural vegetation found in protected zones along the migration route of monarch butterfly. In a latter study, critical habitat blocks to be strengthened will be identified by means of an incentive scheme of CONANP’s Program of Conservation and Sustainable Development (PROCODES, by its acronym in Spanish).
There is a previous study on land vertebrates connectivity in a climate change context (generated through a collaboration between CONANP and WWF- Carlos Slim foundation) which shall also be used as input for obtaining regional connectivity maps during year 2, aligned to institutional and sector objectives.
- Incentive schemes/portfolios that enhance resilience in 8% of the PA of the Project
Efforts have been made in the project at PA San Pedro Mártir so that projects financed by an incentive scheme of Temporary Employment Program (PET) and Conservation Program for Sustainable Development (PROCODES) of CONANP have components which allow for the mitigation and adaptation to Climate Change. During Year 1 an approach has been made to the rest of PA to set this goal and the intention is that at least one PROCODES project for each of the PA be successful in this regard during Year 2.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: PA site management effectively reduces climate-related threats to BD as demonstrated through pilot activities and improved METT scores.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Strengthened management of vulnerable PAs, based on site-specific information generated from pilots in order to address CC risks and threats, with a landscape focus and sustainable productive activities:
a) Increased management capacity of priority PAs reflected in METT scores
b) Cost-effective management actions to reduce vulnerability, to be undertaken in ecoregional clusters (based on 2012 data and to be confirmed by Vulnerability Analysis at end of Year 2) :
These actions will contribute to the surface of improved connectivity in Outcome 2.
- Integrated fire management
- Assisted terrestrial regeneration
- Assisted coastal regeneration
- Assisted marine regeneration
- Sustainable land management
- Prevention, control, eradication, and monitoring of introduced/ invasive species

baseline.comment:
(a) Average METT score 69%
Current METT does not include a resilience component
(b) 0 resilience-based projects or management actions to reduce vulnerability
- 0
- 0
- 0
- 0
- 0
- 100 ha

target.comment:
(a) Increase of 10% in the METT scores (x¯ = 79%)
Recommendation for inclusion of a resilience component in METT, based on EHI and other initiatives, by Year 3.
(b) Resilience-based projects and management actions reduce vulnerability in 12 ecoregional clusters
Target for Year 1 [Final targets TBD based on Vulnerability Analysis at end of Year 2]:
- 6,000 ha + 10 km firebreaks
- 3600 ha +5km gallery forest
- 400 ha
- 200 ha
- 600 ha
- 650 ha

actual.comment:
- Management programs launched with climate change and resilience concepts integrated.
The Project supported devising the Management Program of ÁPFF Manglares de Nichupté, published on the third quarter of Year 1. The Project collaborated in mainstream concepts of climate change and resilience in its components. It is expected that during Years 3 and 4 further modifications will be made to Management Programs having the Project involved.
- The elaboration guidelines of Management programs are under review and modification. One of the main changes proposed is to to include climate change and resilience framework as a subprogram.
The project has participated in the revision of reference terms for the update and devising of Management Programs. It is sought that strategies for facing climate change be included as a main sub program, with the purpose of guaranteeing permanent and planned fulfilment of activities to face climate change.
During Year 1, the identification of key actors was pursued, as well as the devise of initial agreements; this was the basis of the first working session during the last quarter of Year 1. It is planned that this goal is consolidated during Year 2.
- 12% reached of the elaboration of Programs of Adaptation to Climate Change for 12 ecoregional clusters.
On Year 1 PACC for ecoregional cluster including Mapimí and CAD004 Don Martín was published. Updating process begins for PACC Selva El Ocote and Cañón del Sumidero and it is expected to be finished by Year 2. Arising from the implementation of DRV (Outcome 1) the identification of work groups of PACC in 4 other ecoregions has begun; the devising process is estimated to begin during Year 2. For the rest of the Project PA, the process is estimated to be finished during Year 3.
- 100 ha of assisted terrestrial regeneration (3% achieved).
During Year 1, potential sites to carry out sustainable recovery actions in Mapimí BR are identified based on its Climate Change Adaptation Program. Such efforts began as regional approaching; thence, technical activities at a local level shall be taking place during Year 2.
A pasture recovery system was implemented in a first pilot program by means of a transplanter in Mapimí BR, attaining to increase the area of assisted terrestrial generation in 3% with 100 ha.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Improved capacity for planning, implementation and monitoring of site-specific co-managed strategies for increasing resilience in PAs.

baseline.comment:
0 programs/ workshops on resilience in PAs
Average score on Capacity Development Scorecard :
Q 9: 1.625
Q 11: 1.625
Q 13: 1.6875
Q 14: 1.3125
Areas to be improved:
(Q9) Most PAs have adequate Management Programs but are implemented partially or not at all.
(Q11) Environmental information used to support decision making processes is unavailable, incomplete or out-of-date.
(Q13) Capacity and technological needs are, when available, obtained through external financing.
(Q14) Monitoring is done irregularly, with or without an adequate monitoring framework.

target.comment: 12 programs, workshops or courses on resilience in PAs (1 per ecoregional cluster). Average score on Capacity Development Scorecard increases by at least 1 point: Q 9: 2.625, Q 11: 2.625, Q 13: 2.6875, Q 14: 2.3125 Specific improvements: Management instruments are implemented effectively in selected PAs. Information system for adaptive management (Outcome 1). Institutional capacity development program and 3% of CONANP budget (from Outcome 1) reassigned to basic technological needs. National monitoring system with proper capacity building (Outcome 1).

actual.comment:
- Capacity Development of CONANP’s staff and of field officers.
On Year 1 capabilities have been enhanced both within and outside the project personnel.
One of the challenges is guaranteeing that the initiatives developed have permanence beyond that of the estimated life span of the Project. This is proof of the institutional strengthening that is sought in Outcome 1.
Consequently, an e-learning module on Climate Change has been developed within mandatory training 40-hour courses for in-house staff of CONANP. On Year 2 its implementation on the on line learning platform of the institution shall be put into effect.
It was sought that Project operative field personnel had the proper safety capabilities to carry out their activities. Consequently, the project supported 13 out of its 17 field officers at taking up the Safety and first aid course taught by the Mexican Navy. Now the staff is in proper conditions to perform their duties in a safe manner. This knowledge was reinforced by setting up a First Aid kit to offer the necessary tools which were appropriate to the skills developed during the course. During year 2, staff from the Project Coordinating Unit and the totality of field officers shall take up this course so they can all have safety-related topics internalized.
Moreover, regarding safety topics, all field officers and the Project Coordinating Unit received safety training at the UN taught by UNDP.
The Project has supported field officers’ training according to PA-specific needs so they can carry out the activities needed to achieve project’s goals. Every officer has received training on Year 1 and it is planned during year 2 to replicate that training on the rest of the operational staff in their PA. The training taking place is as follows:
(a) Geographic Information System using Quantum GIS freeware.
(b) Prevention and fighting of forest fires.
(c) Ecosystem services monitoring and assessment techniques.
(d) Trainers development for the assessment of PA management effectiveness.
(e) Gender mainstreaming guidelines in mitigation and adaptation to Climate Change efforts, taught by IUCN.
(f) Capacity Works, taught by the German Cooperation for Development (GIZ, by its name in German)
(g) Conflict management and dialogue building, taught by UNDP.
Each of these training courses are planned to be replicated or applied in the PA. In some cases, the abilities of the officer have allowed for the development of capacities in the in-house staff of the PA as well as in members of the civil society. Applying the acquired knowledge in conflict management can be underscored as well as training offered to tourist service providers regarding Climate Change, Sustainable Development and Resilience.
During the report period, it has been spread specialized information regarding different topics associated to climate change among all personnel at the institution, both at the central headquarters in Mexico City and in all other parts of the country. In this regard, the Conference Series on Climate Change has received full support, calling for a second edition which was broadcasted remotely as well as setting personnel on the site to assist those events. Eight master conferences took place, some of them being broadcasted from the different Regional Directorates where the Project is present. The quality and spread of the information has been estimated as able to have an impact on 100 computers remotely connected to the broadcast with an approximate total of 1700 participants, allowing for the creation of Climate Change knowledge networks at different levels.
The information transmitted has been of global policies (Paris 2015 agreement), Carbon Storage, Ecosystem Services Valuation, Risk derived from Climate Change, Governance, Climate Change and Marine Ecosystems, Environmental Education on Climate Change, Carbon Voluntary Markets. These conferences have been institutionalized and are part of the training of the CONANP’s personnel.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Governance framework regarding land-use is strengthened through coordination and gender- and indigenous -sensitive participation forums to consider PA conservation and increased risks associated with CC.

baseline.comment:
Mexico Resiliente Alliance provides an advisory role.
Community Advisory Councils are not engaged in CC resilience. Only 8 of 17 PAs have advisory councils and 2 operate irregularly.
0 Gender organizations and official institutions responsible for gender equality recognized as stakeholders and consulted in PA decision-making processes

target.comment:
Mexico Resiliente Alliance institutionalized as a national advisory council and its members co-implementing at least one project in the field
Strengthened Community advisory councils or ad hoc groups to enhance land use governance in 17 PAs contribute to CC resilience measures/activities.
TBD Gender organizations and official institutions responsible for gender equality recognized as stakeholders and consulted in PA decision-making processes

actual.comment:
18% achieved of Strengthened Community Advisory Councils of PAs on Climate Change and Resilience activities.
During Year 1, 3 out of 17 Advisory Board received training related to the structure of national policies on climate change and about how they may have an impact, from the local level, on decision making and on the configuration of regional policies by means of participation in the design of PACC. During the first quarter of Year 2 this effort shall be repeated in 2 PA and 47% advance is expected to be reached at the end of that period with 8 out of 17 Trained Advisory Boards.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Nivel de avance en la formulación y entrega del documento de diagnóstico de la situación actual de hombres y mujeres en el Estado de Guanajuato 2. Nivel de avance en la elaboración de una propuesta de documento de PRODOC

baseline.comment: Debido a que se trata de un plan de iniciación, no se cuenta con una línea de base.

target.comment: 1. documento de diagnóstico de la situación actual de hombres y mujeres en el Estado formulado y entregado (en los siguientes ámbitos de la estrategia Código Naranja: a) Violencia contra las mujeres; b) Campañas de prevención de la violencia contra mujeres y niñas; c) Modelos de atención a mujeres y niñas víctimas de violencia; d) Protocolos de actuación de procuración de justicia en el marco de violencia contra mujeres y niñas- en particular feminicidios; e) Sensibilización sobre el tema en población juvenil.) 2. Redacción de una nota conceptual para el nuevo documento de proyecto

actual.comment: 1. Completada redacción de documento y entrega formal de productos al Instituto de las Mujeres Guanajuatenses. 2. Se inició la redacción de una nota conceptual para el nuevo documento de proyecto, tomando como insumo los resultados del plan de iniciación y los acuerdos tomados con la contraparte en las reuniones de seguimiento.

target.comment: 1. Completada redacción de documento y entrega formal de productos al Instituto de las Mujeres Guanajuatenses. 2. Redacción del documento de proyecto terminado

actual.comment: 1. Completada redacción de documento y entrega formal de productos al Instituto de las Mujeres Guanajuatenses. 2. Propuesta de documento de PRODOC elaborada. Se encuentra en proceso de revisión por las contrapartes.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
1. nivel de avance en la elaboración de un diagnóstico sobre tipos y grados de discapacidad en niños y niñas con discapacidad que aborde al menos los cinco tipos de discapacidad más comunes en niños y niñas beneficiarias del PEI.
2. nivel de avance en la elaboración de un documento de recomendaciones sobre estándares de accesibilidad física para estancias infantiles diferenciado por tipo de discapacidad y temporalidad de implementación (corto, mediano y largo plazo)
3. nivel de avance en la elaboración de un protocolo de atención y cuidado que aborde la atención de al cinco tipos de discapacidades identificadas en el diagnóstico
4. % de estancias con al menos una persona “responsable” y una “asistente” capacitada entre las 50 estancias seleccionadas para el programa de formación
5. % de “responsables” que adquirieron al menos dos capacidades/habilidades a partir de su participación en el programa de formación
6. % de “asistentes” que adquirieron al menos dos capacidades/habilidades a partir de su participación en el programa de formación
7. % de los familiares del PEI capacitados sobre atención a niños y niñas con discapacidad
8. % de las estancias infantiles seleccionadas para el programa piloto que cambiaron sus protocolos de atención a partir del modelo propuesto por el proyecto
9. % de las responsables que perciben mejoras en la población beneficiaria
10. % de las asistentes que perciben mejoras en la población beneficiaria
11. Número de casos por estancia de niño o niña (ya inscrito en el PEI o que haya solicitado admisión y por su condición haya sido derivado a otra institución) a partir de la implementación del protocolo de derivación
12. % de los familiares de la población objetivo que afirma identificar una mejora en los procesos de atención y cuidado por parte de las estancias a partir de la implementación del modelo de atención y cuidado
13. Número de adecuación de accesibilidad implementadas en cada estancia
14. Número de recomendacione

baseline.comment: La línea base se determinará previo a la implementación del programa de formación y tomando como referencia el perfil de la figura de “responsables” y “asistentes” La línea base se levantará previo a la implementación del programa piloto para identificar los cambios en los modelos de atención Para el resto de los indicadores la línea base es cero.

target.comment: 1. Elaborar un diagnóstico en estancias infantiles con niñas y niños con discapacidad para detección de los tipos de discapacidades y grados existentes en la población beneficiaria del Programa de Estancias Infantiles 2. Elaborar un documento de recomendaciones sobre accesibilidad física construido a partir de las características y contexto de las estancias infantiles y los estándares internacionales en materia de discapacidad 3. Elaborar un protocolo de atención y cuidado inclusivo a partir de los resultados del diagnóstico. El protocolo estará dirigido a personal de las estancias infantiles para mejorar el cuidado y atención de niños y niñas con discapacidad en el marco del Programa de Estancias Infantiles

actual.comment: A ser completado sobre la base del avance del proyecto.
